message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The screening blood test used in this situation is the interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA), which is used to diagnose latent tuberculosis infection. The peptides added to the sample specifically stimulate the production of interferon-gamma by T cells that have been sensitized to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The other options are not associated with sensitivity to interferon-gamma and would not be helpful in diagnosing infection using this test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The screening blood test described in the question is for tuberculosis infection, which is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The test measures interferon-gamma production in response to specific peptides derived from M. tuberculosis antigens. None of the other options are associated with interferon-gamma production in response to specific peptides.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The screening blood test that stimulates in vitro production of interferon-gamma is used to detect latent tuberculosis infection. None of the other options are associated with this type of screening test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The test described is known as interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA), and it is used to diagnose tuberculosis. The other options are not primarily associated with tuberculosis, and therefore, the IGRA would not be useful in diagnosing these infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The screening blood test that stimulates in vitro production of interferon-gamma is called an interferon gamma release assay (IGRA), and it is used to diagnose tuberculosis (TB) infection. So the correct answer is Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
